awd_titl_txt: E2CDA: Type I: Collaborative Research: Nanophotonic Neuromorphic Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
With this program, the National Science Foundation has challenged the scientific community to help solve the problem of energy efficient computing. Data centers around the world spend almost equal amount of overhead power in cooling and power conversion for every Watt of computation. As society's appetite for information continues to grow, data centers will eventually consume a significant portion of the world's electricity. Today, the entire information technology industry relies on digital electronics, i.e. electrons carrying digital bits, which impose a barrier for how efficient a computational task can be, regardless of how brilliantly software routines can be engineered. This project will explore the physics of lightwaves to craft a "photonic" processor that breaks that efficiency barrier. This interdisciplinary endeavor will attempt to generate foundational science which will support future innovation in the tech industry. To the end of help building the workforce for the future, the investigators will continue their commitments in mentoring graduate and undergraduate students, and support broadening participation of women, minorities and underrepresented groups through STEM outreach, and NSF REU sites.

The approach unites neuromorphic (neural network-inspired) architectures, nanophotonic devices, and emerging fabrication platforms. The technical challenge requires vertical integration of new optical devices, logic units, and control software. It utilizes diverse expertise of faculty members in nanophotonic devices, photonic systems and computer engineering. Specifically, the key points of innovation will include: 1) ultra-efficient electro-optic modulators that will act as neurons at the nanoscale; 2) reconfigurable hardware interconnection fabric on-chip that uses light as information carrier; and 3) creation of control software and benchmarks that are required to orient the project within the broader field of efficient computing. A strong experimental thrust to design, build, and demonstrate these proposed systems will serve to reduce the risk of development of this technology and pave the way for other researchers to join the emerging field of nanophotonic neuromorphic computing.

por.por_cntn:
As microelectronics fails to maintain rates of processor evolution in speed, efficiency, and generality, it becomes increasingly clear that conventional computers are no longer capable of being the one-size-fits-all approach to computing problems. This is especially true for the multiply-accumulate operations which are key to the rise of modern artificial intelligence. Unconventional computing architectures are therefore being explored to address this widening gap between application demands and hardware. In this collaborative project, we set out to demonstrate a neuromorphic (i.e. brain-inspired) photonic (i.e. light-based) computing platform. Photonic phenomena can be employed to implement analog weighted addition with unmatched speed, efficiency, and scalability. Furthermore, photonic transport physics can support massively distributed interconnections with commensurate performance.

As part of this NSF project, we have made great strides towards this goal. In Year 1, we fabricated, tested, and explored the properties of III-V laser neurons 10 000x faster than biological neurons. We showed that these devices could implement spike processing at GHz speeds and with sub-ns temporal precision. In Year 2, we studied how photonic neurons can be networked. We did this through an “autapse”, a self-connection. By showing the neuron could drive itself, we established that the units can regenerate signals and that information processing in networks is possible. In order to move toward the experimental demonstration of a network of like units, we began the study of photonic structure that could emulate neural connections. This involved considering a more scalable platform, silicon photonics. A non-laser, non-spiking photonic neuron compatible with silicon was developed and its autapse behaviour similarly successfully characterized. At the onset of Year 3, a chip containing an array of neural weights and neurons was taped out to study networks. To be able to control such a large-scale chip, we developed packaging techniques and large-scale control methods. At the outset of this award, we have therefore have all the components required to experiment on photonic neural networks with multiple neurons and tackle applications.

Practical outcomes of the award include over 25 journal articles, conference presentations, and book chapters. Furthermore, many of the techniques developed for photonic device simulation, chip layout, and lab automation were disseminated as part of Prof. Prucnal`s graduate course on Photonic Systems. The packages, which are entirely open-source, are also available to the general public at https://github.com/lightwave-lab.
